title: Just found out child's father filed for bankruptcy, he owes me $150,000 in child support!
question: Father is doctor, he ran up $150,000 arrearage(his lawyer and him know the local judge) He concealed his BK from me so I couldn't inquire about his income (local judge denied any discovery to me). He also didn't want me telling trustee about his income/assets he is hiding. It's still open, I filed a proof of priority claim, but can I ask the BK judge to set a payment plan for the c/s? Trustee didn't do a good job of reviewing his claims. I just don't know how he was able to file hiding all his income, all the lawyers knew he owed $150,000 in c/s. Why was I not notified? Plus he only stated 3 creditors, he owes so many people money. Will the bk judge let me have a creditors meeting at this late time and make him pay the arrearage? Will he get in trouble for lying about his inc/assets?
answers:
What the other attorneys have stated about the bankruptcy not wiping out the child support debt to you is correct. However, there is a provision in the bankruptcy laws that were enacted in 2005 that says the Bankruptcy Trustee can reach all assets, even exempt assets for the purpose of collecting back support. In 9 years I have never seen this used to make the trustee pursue the debtor but it can be done. I would have to look up the relevant section but it is there.

Yes you can try to get him denied a discharge as the attorney's have stated. However, as a practical matter, that may not be in your best interest. The reason I am saying that is that the discharge will wipe out the other creditors so they are not competing with your attempts to collect the debt. Why would you want to be fighting with other creditors for the same money.

I would look into what you can get the Bankruptcy trustee to do to aid collection. I would also ask the District Attorney Family Support Division to help collect the support arrears and ongoing support payments. A family court order is still an order and can be enforced by the DA.

If you know of assets that are PROVABLE, then the trustee can and will go after them. The Trustee however is not going to fight this battle if you cannot prove that there is assets to go after so they can get paid. The trustee cannot work for free and only gets paid $60 per case if there are no assets. If there are assets that are reachable, the Trustee is going to try to collect as that is the only cases he will get paid a decent amount for handling.

The other attorneys are correct in telling you that the individual running the Creditor's Meeting is a Trustee or representative of the Trustee. He or she is not a judge.

If you have proof that the debtor is hiding assets or committing any other bankruptcy fraud, you can report that information to the United States Trustee by submitting a fraud complaint in the format and in accordance with the procedures discussed at the link shown below.

The debt is not dischargeable so you can proceed to collect against him (why have you not already) upon the discharge of his case. If you do not want him to get a discharge you can file an adversary proceeding under section 727 of the bankruptcy code but that would likely do nothing but waste attorneys fees. Your best option is likely to report your concerns to the US Trustee.

One of the other answers here refers you to the US Trustee's Office. Bankruptcy crimes are also reported to the Federal Bureau of Investigation as well as the US Attorney's Office.

Typically the US Trustee's office is the first to find out but not necessarily. The Department of Justice is the first stop on the whistle stop tour.

Here is the link:

http://www.justice.gov/ust/eo/fraud/
Proof of lying under oath should be reporting to the United States Trustee for your area (region 17) There is link below.

Child support is non-dischargeable in bankruptcy. It is a priority claim listed on Schedule E of the BK petition, "Unsecured Priority Claims." It would violate public policy to have this debt discharged.

You have nothing to fear here.

Best of luck!

I'm curious how you discovered the father filed a bankruptcy if you didn't receive a notice from the bankruptcy court. He had to list your claim because it is a debt he owes even though it won't be discharged in bankruptcy court. The bankruptcy judge doesn't have anything to do with forcing the father to pay the back child support. Your remedy is in state court - domestic relations division. That's where you should focus your energy.

Child support is not discharged in bankruptcy. Your claim is a priority, so any funds that become available will go toward that first. You can inform the trustee of hidden assets. However, bankruptcy court is not the place to do more than what you have done. If you want to enforce the support order, you need to go to family court.
